INTRODUCTION AND READING OF BILLS
A Local Law to amend the New York city charter in relation to the review and approval of franchises.
Items.ActionText: This Introduction was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Land Use
Items.MatterName: In relation to the review and approval of franchises.

Items.Title: Resolution calling upon the New York City Department of Education to help increase compliance with Section 809 of the New York State Education Law, which requires instruction on the humane treatment and protection of animals, by issuing a memorandum to all New York City public schools that notifies them of the humane education mandate in Section 809 and by requiring that all elementary school principals direct their teachers to act in accordance with this requirement.
Items.ActionText: This Resolution was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Education
Items.MatterName: Require instruction on the humane treatment and protection of animals, by memorandum to all NYC public schools to notify them of the humane education mandate in Section 809.

Items.Title: Resolution urging the State Legislature and the Governor to amend the Municipal Home Rule Law to ensure that multiple validly created charter revision commissions may submit ballot questions to be proposed during the same election.
Items.ActionText: This Resolution was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Governmental Operations
Items.MatterName: Ensure that multiple validly created charter revision commissions may submit ballot questions to be proposed during the same election.

Items.Title: Resolution calling upon the State Legislature and the Governor to amend the Municipal Home Rule Law by placing limitations on the number of consecutive charter revision commissions that may be created by the Mayor of the City of New York pursuant to Municipal Home Rule Law §36(4).
Items.ActionText: This Resolution was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Governmental Operations
Items.MatterName: Placing limitations on the number of consecutive charter revision commissions that may be created by the Mayor of the City of New York pursuant to Municipal Home Rule Law §36(4).

Items.Title: A Local Law in relation to establishing separate units of appropriation for uniformed personnel overtime in the city budget.
Items.ActionText: This Introduction was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Finance
Items.MatterName: Establishing separate units of appropriation for uniformed personnel overtime in the city budget.

Items.Title: Resolution calling upon Congress to increase funding to the Women, Infants and Children program and to continue the Commodity Supplemental Food Program.
Items.ActionText: This Resolution was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on General Welfare
Items.MatterName: Congress to increase funding to the Women, Infants and Children program and to continue the Commodity Supplemental Food Program.

Items.ActionText: This Introduction was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Housing and Buildings

Items.Title: A Local Law to amend the administrative code of the city of New York, in relation to the maintenance of sprinkler systems in certain residential occupancies.
Items.ActionText: This Introduction was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Housing and Buildings
Items.MatterName: Maintenance of sprinkler systems in certain residential occupancies.

Items.Title: A Local Law to amend the administrative code of the city of New York, in relation to the distribution of unsolicited printed material to any building or premises and to repeal subdivision five of section 16-118 of such code.
Items.ActionText: This Introduction was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Sanitation and Solid Waste Management
Items.MatterName: Distribution of unsolicited printed material to any building or premises and to repeal subdivision five of section 16-118 of such code.

Items.Title: Resolution calling upon the New York State Legislature to pass and the Governor to sign A.231, an act to amend the alcoholic beverage control law, in relation to authorizing the creation of an alcoholic beverage control board in and by the City of New York.

Items.MatterName: Authorizing the creation of an alcoholic beverage control board in and by the City of New York.

Items.ActionText: This Resolution was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Consumer Affairs
Items.MatterName: Ban the practice and licensure of applicants proposing “bottle service” in the state of New York.

Items.AgendaNote: The Public Advocate (Ms. Gotbaum) put the question whether the Council would agree with and adopt such reports, which were decided in the affirmative by the following vote:
Items.MinutesNote: The Public Advocate (Ms. Gotbaum) put the question whether the Council would agree with and adopt such reports, which were decided in the affirmative by the following vote:

Items.AgendaNote:
The following files were removed from the General Order Calendar and voted separately: 

Int No. 296-A (Veto Override); 
M-277 & Res No. 517, M-282 & Res No. 521, M-283 & Res 522.

See files for individual votes.

With the vote of 43-6-0, the Mayor's Veto of Int No. 296-A was overridden by the Council and Int No. 296-A thereby was enacted into law and subsequently assigned as Local Law 
38 of 2006.
Items.MinutesNote:
The following files were removed from the General Order Calendar and voted separately:

Int 296-A (Veto Override); M-276 (Filed)
M-277 & Res No. 517; M-282 & Res No. 521; M-283 & Res No. 522.

See files for individual votes.

With the vote of 43-6-0, the Mayor's Veto of Int No. 296-A was Overridden by the Council
and Int No. 296-A thereby became law and was subsequently assigned as Local Law No.
38 of 2006.

Pursuant to Rule 8.50 of the Council, the Public Advocate (Ms. Gotbaum) called for a voice vote.  Hearing no objections, the Public Advocate (Ms. Gotbaum) declared the Resolution to be adopted.

Adopted unanimously by the Council by voice-vote.

At this point, the Speaker asked for a Moment of Silence in memory of the following individuals:

Capt. John J. McKenna IV, 30, from the Windsor Terrace section of Brooklyn, died on August 16, 2006 while conducting combat operations in Al Anbar province, Iraq.  He was assigned to Marine Forces Reserve's 2nd Battalion, 25th Marine Regiment, 4th Marine Divison, Albany, N.Y.  Heis survivedby his parents and his sister.

Lance Cpl. Michael D. Glover, 28, born in the Rockaways, died on August 16, 2006 while conducting combat operations in Al Anbar province, Iraq,  in the same skirmish that killed Captian McKenna above.  He was assigned to Marine Forces Reserve's 2nd Battalion, 25th Marine Regiment, 4th Marine Division, Albany, N.Y.  Cpl. Glover is survived by his parents, grandparents and sister.
